Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Atlas of Lie Groups and Representation Theory: Computational Aspects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of The Atlas of Lie Groups and Representations project is to solve a fundamental problem in representation theory of Lie groups: the classification of the irreducible unitary representations of real reductive Lie groups. The contributors are taking a computational approach to the problem. They have developed the mathematical theory required to reduce the problem to a finite computation. This required rethinking representation theory from the ground up from this new point of view. The key tool is a modified notion of invariant Hermitian form, called the c-Hermitian form, which has critical uniqueness properties lacking in the usual Hermitian form. This allows the formulation of an algorithm to compute the sign of c-Hermitian and Hermitian forms, in terms of a new family of Kazhdan-Lusztig-Vogan polynomials.

Symmetry plays a fundamental role in mathematics and the sciences. In the late 19th century Sophus Lie showed that the symmetry of a system can be captured in an abstract mathematical object; these are now known as Lie (pronounced Lee) groups. The ways in which a particular symmetry (i.e. Lie) group can manifest itself are known as unitary representations. The main goal of the Atlas of Lie Groups and Representations is to understand all such representations. This has applications to physics, as well as many areas of mathematics, including number theory and geometry. The approach is computational. Both the mathematical and computational challenges are great, and the project brings together mathematicians and computer scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Symmetry plays a fundamental role in mathematics and science. The underlying symmetries of a system form a Lie group, and for this reason Lie groups play an important role in the applications of symmetry principles.

Representation theory describes the ways in which Lie groups can arise as symmetry groups.  An important long standing problem in representation theory is that of the ``Unitary Dual''. This problem originates in work of Hermann Weyl on quantum mechanices about 100 years ago. The problem is to classify all of the unitary representations of a given Lie group; in effect, all of the ways in which the Lie group can appear as a symmetry group.

It is well known that the Unitary Dual of a given Lie group is often a very complicated object. The primary goal of the Atlas of Lie groups is to study the unitary dual problem with the aid of a computer.  The project began in 2003. During the period of the grant the project achieved a major goal: it can now determine whether any given representation of a Lie group is unitary, and therefore in principal determine the unitary dual. Achieving this goal required rethinking all of the theory of Lie groups and representations with algorithms in mind. In February 2018 we released Version 1.0 of the software, which is freely available via the project web site www.liegroups.org.

The project has led to a new and deeper understanding of the field of representation theory. One of the key discoveries of the project is the notion of the c-invariant form. This has led to the discovery of a connection between unitary representations and geometry (Hodge theory) which (conjecturally) gives an entirely new viewpoint on the unitary dual. 

The Atlas project is innovative in applying computational ideas to a very abstract problem in pure mathematics. The success of the project (which was by no means guaranteed!) suggests that the computational approach has potential in other areas of mathematics. 

In addition to the primary application to the Unitary dual, the project has led to a number of results in representation theory,including a result (the contragredient) which has had an impact in the Langlands program, and structural results (Galois cohomology) which unify and simplify a number of basic result in the field.

Broader Impacts

The second primary goal of the Atlas project is to provide software to make computations in representation theory accessible to a wide audience. This includes researchers in other branches of mathematics, physics, statistics, and other areas, who are interested in using representation theory but are not experts in it. The software is being used by a growing number of researchers for this purpose. One of theaccomplishments of the project during the period of the grant was the creation of the Atlas documentation site www.liegroups.org/help. The software also provides an entry into the technical field of the representation theory, and has been used in teaching the subject at the University of Maryland and elsewhere.
